item.title: 48 Core CPU
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I don’t think it will take long for all software to be developed in a manner that automatically allows it to scale as much as possible.
Virtual machine software makes this quite simple for the programmer to implement in a language such as Java. I imagine it’s comparably easy in C# too.

Read full topic

item.title: 48 Core CPU
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I don’t see on there what instruction set or architecture it supports.

I found the answer to my own question:

http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/8392392.stm:

the SCC is based on Intel’s X86 architecture

Not even 64-bit? That sucks.

Also, linux is awesome:[quote=“http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/8392392.stm”]Intel said it had already demonstrated Linux running on each core. It has also found a way to slash the management overhead required to keep the processors crunching data in synch.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: 48 Core CPU

item.description:
@The_Flames wrote:

BBC News sauce:
http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/8392392.stm

In 2007, the firm showed off an 80-core processor, whilst earlier this year a US firm called Tilera announced a 100-core chip. Also graphics chip maker Nvidia has previewed its next-generation processor that has 512 cores.

I’m liking the 512 cores concept.

item.title: 48 Core CPU
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:10, topic:317273”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=413819.msg3047151#msg3047151 date=1259816193]
I don’t see on there what instruction set or architecture it supports.
[/quote]
I doubt that it would be anything other than x86, since it is the only architecture that needs 48 cores to work well.[/quote]

Actually all of the dual and quad core CPUs that I know of today run the amd64 architecture, not x86.

There are some specialized applications, such as audio and video decoders and rendering of graphics that may use 4 or 8 cores, but for a desktop or laptop computer doing normal things, most cores would never be touched.

Read full topic

item.title: 48 Core CPU
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I don’t see on there what instruction set or architecture it supports.

I doubt that it would be anything other than x86-64, since it is the only architecture that needs 48 cores to work well.

Aren’t m$ developing a operating system that is purpose built to utilize several cores and concentrates on parallelism?

Read full topic

item.title: 48 Core CPU
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I don’t see on there what instruction set or architecture it supports. You would want to have a lot of RAM in a computer like that. Anyhow, it is still big time overkill, as there aren’t even any applications that I know of that scale neatly over 4 cores, with 48 you would have 46 of them unused most of the time.

moparscape servers would scale well. er, up to around 47 or so players. then they would suck as usual.

Read full topic

I don’t see on there what instruction set or architecture it supports. You would want to have a lot of RAM in a computer like that. Anyhow, it is still big time overkill, as there aren’t even any applications that I know of that scale neatly over 4 cores, with 48 you would have 46 of them unused most of the time.
[/quote]

There are applications that use all of 8 cores that I’ve used.[/quote]
I’ve found that if im rendering something with a 3D application or perhaps after effects i get all 8 of my CPU threads being used

NZ Herald – 2 Dec 09

Intel announces 48-core powerhouse processor
